Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of MIRTH: A Novel Catheter-Based Intramyocardial Ventricular Remodeling Procedure

Background: MIRTH is a novel catheter-based intramyocardial ventricular remodeling procedure designed to reduce left ventricular chamber dimensions and wall stress, improving cardiac performance in cardiomyopathic animals.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial involved juvenile Yorkshire swine with healthy myocardium or ischemic cardiomyopathy. Animals were randomly assigned to receive MIRTH or serve as controls. The primary outcome was the change in left ventricular performance, measured by contractility and mechanical efficiency, over a 90-day period. Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Results: A total of 33 animals were randomised: 17 with healthy myocardium and 16 with ischemic cardiomyopathy. MIRTH significantly improved left ventricular performance in cardiomyopathic animals, with increased contractility and mechanical efficiency (p < 0.05). No adverse events related to myocardial erosion were observed. Two early implants failed due to suture abrasion, prompting a change to ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene suture.

Interpretation: MIRTH offers a promising approach to ventricular remodeling, demonstrating significant improvements in cardiac performance in cardiomyopathic swine. Further studies are needed to explore its potential in clinical settings.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: Supported by the Division of Intramural Research, National Heart Lung and Blood Institute, National Institutes of Health USA (grant Z01-HL006040).
